Human Chronotype Is Determined by Period Oscillations

mods:mods.abstract: Circadian clocks are endogenous timekeepers, but they need to be synchronized, or entrained, with external cues such as solar time to stay in harmony with the external environment. The circadian clocks give selective advantages to humans by adapting and optimizing our body system in this 24 h living environment. These intrinsic circadian clocks intertwine with nearly all aspects of human physiology. Thus, disruption of circadian clocks is closely associated with diverse disease conditions such as metabolic, cardiovascular, and sleep diseases. Sleeping is regulated by two internal mechanisms, homeostasis and circadian rhythms. These two internal biological systems are synchronized with environmental cues to optimize the timing and duration of sleep closely related to the quality of life. More than 70 million people suffer from sleep disorders in the U.S. The deprivation of sleep interferes not only with cognitive function but also with personal mood. Specifically, circadian rhythm sleep disorders (CRSD) are caused by alterations in the endogenous circadian time-keeping system itself or a misalignment between the endogenous circadian clock and external circumstances. The CRSD patients are primarily treated by pharmacological strategies by targeting melatonin, orexin, or core clock genes. Behavioral approaches such as light exposure adjustment and scheduled feeding have reported promising outcomes. However, understanding the molecular mechanism and genetics of human CRSDs is at a very early stage. We examined the molecular mechanism of PERIOD (PER), a key factor in the circadian clock, by generating PER1-Luc and PER2-Luc cell lines using the CRISPR-mediated HDR system. This allowed us to monitor PER1/2 oscillations in real-time. Next, we targeted several key amino acids in the PAS and CKBD domains and monitored PER oscillation to identify functional sequence motifs in Per1/2. Our study revealed that PAS dimerization-induced phosphorylation is crucial for PER oscillations, leading to its translocation into the nucleus. Additionally, we explored the diverse roles of functional sequence motifs in CKBD. Deletion of FASP in-frame mutant PER1 and PER2 shortened the period, while newly synthesized FASP mutants accelerated phosphorylation and underwent hyperphosphorylation and earlier degradation. Mutants in CK1BD-A or CK1BD-B exhibited defective phosphorylation, resulting in a lengthened period. In CK1BD-B mutant PER2, hPer1 knockout disrupted phosphorylation, rendering PER2 stable and arrhythmic. Furthermore, we created PER1 and PER2 PAS B mutant mice, with Per1W448E/W448E; Per2W419E/W419E mice displaying a human FASP chronotype. These findings significantly enhance our understanding of PER's functional role in sustaining circadian clocks and regular sleep-wake cycles. We demonstrated the invaluable utility of PER-Luc reporter cell lines as a resource for studying the circadian clock. Additionally, we introduced a method for generating mutant mice with disrupted circadian rhythms. Through our approach, it becomes feasible to create mouse models mimicking human sleep disorders effortlessly. While our focus was on investigating functional sequence motifs in PER, the experimental approach employed in this study could be extended to other clock genes for studying sleep disorders.
